## Observation 5: EnchantÃ©(e)

>
> "En Belgique, on dit toujours 'Bonjour' quand on entre dans un magasin, une boulangerie, un cafÃ©... C'est malpoli de ne pas le faire !"

### Comprehension

**Answer the questions:**

1. How is the baker doing? *(Comment va le boulanger ?)*
2. What does Tom want to buy? *(Qu'est-ce que Tom veut acheter ?)*

## Observation 1: Comment Ã§a va ?

### Vocabulary: Comment Ã§a va ?

| French | Pronunciation | English |
|:---------|:--------------|:--------|
| Comment Ã§a va ? | [kÉ”mÉ‘Ìƒ sa va] | How are you? (informal) |
| Ã‡a va bien | [sa va bjÉ›Ìƒ] | I'm fine |

## Practice 1: Comment Ã§a va ?

## Observation 2: S'il vous plaÃ®t

**Look at this part of the dialogue:**

> **Tom :** Je voudrais un pain, **s'il vous plaÃ®t**.

**What do you notice?**

- When asking for something, we add **"s'il vous plaÃ®t"**
- "S'il vous plaÃ®t" = "Please" in English
- It is ESSENTIAL in Belgium!

### Formal vs Informal

| Situation | French | English |
|:----------|:---------|:--------|
| With a shopkeeper | S'il **vous** plaÃ®t | Please (formal) |

## Practice 2: S'il vous plaÃ®t

**Ask for these things politely:**

1. A coffee â†’ "Un cafÃ©, _______________."

<summary>ğŸ“ Answers</summary>

1. Un cafÃ©, **s'il vous plaÃ®t**.

---

## Observation 3: Merci and responses

**Look at this part of the dialogue:**

**What do you notice?**

- To thank â†’ **Merci** or **Merci beaucoup**

### Vocabulary: Merci and responses

| French | English | Usage |
|:---------|:--------|:------|
| Merci | Thank you | Standard |

## Observation 4: Bonne journÃ©e

**Look at the end of the dialogue:**

> **Boulanger :** **Bonne journÃ©e !**

**What do you notice?**

| French | English | When? |
|:---------|:--------|:--------|
| Bonne journÃ©e | Have a nice day | During the day |
| Bonne soirÃ©e | Have a nice evening | In the evening |
| Bon week-end | Have a nice weekend | Friday/Saturday |
| Ã€ bientÃ´t | See you soon | When seeing each other soon |

---

## Culture: Politeness in Belgium

### Read this testimonial

**Sarah, American expat in Brussels:**

> **En franÃ§ais**
>
> "Au dÃ©but, je ne disais pas 'Bonjour' en entrant dans les magasins. Les commerÃ§ants Ã©taient froids avec moi ! Maintenant, je dis toujours 'Bonjour' en entrant et 'Merci, bonne journÃ©e !' en sortant. Les Belges sont beaucoup plus chaleureux !"

> **In English**

> "At first, I didn't say 'Bonjour' when entering shops. The shopkeepers were cold to me! Now, I always say 'Bonjour' when entering and 'Merci, bonne journÃ©e!' when leaving. Belgians are much warmer!"

### The Golden Rules of Belgian Politeness

| âœ… Do | âŒ Don't |
|:----------|:-----------|
| "Bonjour !" when entering | Entering without saying anything |
| "S'il vous plaÃ®t" when asking | Asking without "s'il vous plaÃ®t" |
| "Merci !" after a service | Leaving without thanking |
| "Bonne journÃ©e !" when leaving | Leaving silently |

---

## Observation 5: The verb AVOIR

**Listen to this conversation with Sophie:**

> **Sophie :** Tu as un rendez-vous Ã  la commune ?
> 
> **Tom :** Oui, **j'ai** un rendez-vous Ã  14h. Et toi ?
> 
> **Sophie :** Moi, **j'ai** une rÃ©union. On **a** beaucoup de travail aujourd'hui !

**What do you notice?**

- "J'ai" = "I have"
- "Tu as" = "You have"

| French | English |

2. _______ une voiture ? (tu)
3. Sophie _______ un rendez-vous. (elle)

<details>
<summary>ğŸ“ Answers</summary>

1. **J'ai** un frÃ¨re.
2. **Tu as** une voiture ?

---

## Speaking Practice

### Exercise 1: At the Bakery

**Roleplay this dialogue:**

**Vendeur :** Bonjour !  
**Vous :** Bonjour ! _______________? (Comment Ã§a va ?)  
**Vendeur :** Ã‡a va bien, merci ! Vous dÃ©sirez ?

---

## Writing Practice

**Write a short dialogue (5-6 exchanges) in a cafÃ©.**

Include:
- Bonjour
- Comment Ã§a va ?

- Bonne journÃ©e

---

## Grammar: Recap

### The verb AVOIR (to have)

# Lesson 04: Family and relationships

**Level**: A1.1

**Objectives**: Talk about your family, describe relatives, use possessive adjectives (my, your, his/her)

---

## ğŸ§ Let's Start! Tom's Family

### Listen to this conversation

**Sophie and Tom meet at a party in Brussels:**

> **Sophie :** Parle-moi de **ta** famille !
> 
> **Tom :** D'accord ! J'ai un frÃ¨re et une sÅ“ur. **Mon** frÃ¨re habite Ã  Londres et **ma** sÅ“ur habite Ã  Paris.
> 
> **Sophie :** Et **tes** parents ?
> 
> **Tom :** **Mes** parents habitent en Angleterre.
> 
> **Sophie :** Tu es mariÃ© ?
> 
> **Tom :** Oui ! **Ma** femme s'appelle Sarah.

> **Sophie :** Vous avez des enfants ?

> **Tom :** Non, pas encore. Et toi ?
> 
> **Sophie :** J'ai deux enfants : **mon** fils a dix ans et **ma** fille a huit ans.

<details>
<summary>English Translation</summary>

> **Sophie:** Tell me about **your** family!
> 
> **Tom:** Okay! I have a brother and a sister. **My** brother lives in London and **my** sister lives in Paris.
> 
> **Sophie:** And **your** parents?
> 
> **Tom:** **My** parents live in England.
> 
> **Sophie:** Are you married?
> 
> **Tom:** Yes! **My** wife's name is Sarah.
> 
> **Sophie:** Do you have children?
> 
> **Tom:** No, not yet. And you?
> 
> **Sophie:** I have two children: **my** son is ten years old and **my** daughter is eight years old.

</details>

---

## ğŸ” Step 1: Talking about YOUR own family (My)

**Look at what Tom says about himself:**

- **mon** frÃ¨re (brother - masculine)
- **ma** sÅ“ur (sister - feminine)
- **mes** parents (parents - plural)

**The Rule for "MY":**

| Masculine (Je) | Feminine (Je) | Plural (Je) |
|:---|:---|:---|
| **mon** | **ma** | **mes** |
| *mon pÃ¨re* | *ma mÃ¨re* | *mes parents* |
| *mon frÃ¨re* | *ma sÅ“ur* | *mes enfants* |

> **ğŸ’¡ Important:** In French, the word agrees with the **family member**, not with you!
> - Tom says "**ma** femme" (because *femme* is feminine).
> - Sophie says "**mon** fils" (because *fils* is masculine).

---

## âœï¸ Practice 1: My family

**Complete with mon, ma, or mes:**

1. J'ai un frÃ¨re. ______ frÃ¨re s'appelle Pierre.
2. J'ai une sÅ“ur. ______ sÅ“ur habite Ã  Lyon.

4. J'ai une voiture. C'est ______ voiture.

<details>
<summary>ğŸ“ Answers</summary>

1. **Mon** frÃ¨re
2. **Ma** sÅ“ur
3. **Mes** enfants
4. **Ma** voiture

</details>

---

## ğŸ” Step 2: Talking about YOUR FRIEND'S family (Your)

**Look at what Sophie asks Tom:**

> "Parle-moi de **ta** famille !"
> "Et **tes** parents ?"

**The Rule for "YOUR" (Informal - Tu):**

| Masculine (Tu) | Feminine (Tu) | Plural (Tu) |
|:---|:---|:---|
| **ton** | **ta** | **tes** |
| *ton pÃ¨re* | *ta mÃ¨re* | *tes parents* |

**Example:**
- "C'est **ton** frÃ¨re ?" (Is that your brother?)
- "C'est **ta** sÅ“ur ?" (Is that your sister?)

---

## âœï¸ Practice 2: Asking questions

**Ask a friend about their family. Complete with ton, ta, tes:**

1. Comment s'appelle ______ pÃ¨re ?
2. OÃ¹ habite ______ mÃ¨re ?
3. ______ enfants sont Ã  l'Ã©cole ?
4. C'est ______ mari sur la photo ?

<details>
<summary>ğŸ“ Answers</summary>

1. **ton** pÃ¨re
2. **ta** mÃ¨re
3. **tes** enfants
4. **ton** mari

</details>

---

## ğŸ” Step 3: Talking about SOMEONE ELSE'S family (His/Her)

**Now visualize Tom talking about his wife Sarah:**
> "**Son** pÃ¨re est amÃ©ricain." (Her father is American)

**The Rule for "HIS/HER" (Il/Elle):**

| Masculine (Il/Elle) | Feminine (Il/Elle) | Plural (Il/Elle) |
|:---|:---|:---|
| **son** | **sa** | **ses** |
| *son pÃ¨re* | *sa mÃ¨re* | *ses parents* |

> **âš ï¸ CRITICAL DIFFERENCE WITH ENGLISH:**
> In English, "his" = for a man, "her" = for a woman.
> **In French, it depends on the OBJECT/PERSON being possessed!**
>
> - **Son** frÃ¨re (can mean *his* brother OR *her* brother).
> - **Sa** sÅ“ur (can mean *his* sister OR *her* sister).
>
> Context tells you whose brother or sister it is.

---

## âœï¸ Practice 3: Mon/Ma, Ton/Ta, or Son/Sa?

**Choose the right word:**

1. (Me) -> Je parle de ___ mÃ¨re. (**mon** / **ma**)
2. (You) -> Tu parles de ___ pÃ¨re ? (**ton** / **ta**)
3. (Him/Her) -> Sophie parle de ___ frÃ¨re. (**son** / **sa**)
4. (Me) -> J'aime ___ parents. (**mon** / **mes**)

<details>
<summary>ğŸ“ Answers</summary>

1. **ma** mÃ¨re
2. **ton** pÃ¨re
3. **son** frÃ¨re (because *frÃ¨re* is masculine, even if Sophie is a woman!)
4. **mes** parents

</details>

---

## ğŸ“– Grammar Summary: Singular Possessives

**We focus only on Singular owners for now (Me, You, Him/Her).**

| Owner | Masculine Object | Feminine Object | Plural Objects |
|:---|:---:|:---:|:---:|
| **Je** (My) | **mon** | **ma** | **mes** |
| **Tu** (Your) | **ton** | **ta** | **tes** |
| **Il/Elle** (His/Her) | **son** | **sa** | **ses** |

### âš ï¸ Special Rule: Feminine starting with a vowel
If a feminine word starts with use vowel (a, e, i, o, u, y), use the **Masculine** form (mon/ton/son).

- *Une amie* (friend) -> **Mon** amie (NOT Ma amie)
- *Une Ã©cole* (school) -> **Ton** Ã©cole (NOT Ta Ã©cole)
- *Une histoire* (story) -> **Son** histoire (NOT Sa histoire)

---

## ğŸ“š Vocabulary: Family Members

| French | English |
|:---|:---|
| **Les Parents** | **Parents** |
| Le pÃ¨re / Papa | Father / Dad |
| La mÃ¨re / Maman | Mother / Mom |
| **Les Enfants** | **Children** |
| Le fils | Son |
| La fille | Daughter |
| **La Fratrie** | **Siblings** |
| Le frÃ¨re | Brother |
| La sÅ“ur | Sister |
| **Le Couple** | **Couple** |
| Le mari | Husband |
| La femme | Wife |

---

## âœ… Self-Evaluation

- [ ] I can talk about **my** family (mon/ma/mes).
- [ ] I can ask someone about **their** family (ton/ta/tes).
- [ ] I can describe **someone else's** family (son/sa/ses).
- [ ] I understand that "son/sa" depends on the *family member's gender*, not the owner's!

# Lesson 04 Bis: Module 1 Revision

Well done! You have finished the first 4 lessons. It is time to **take stock**.

## 1. Identity & Greetings (Recap Lessons 01 & 02)

### The Golden Rule

Saying "Bonjour" when entering somewhere is not an option. It is **mandatory**.

## 2. Numbers & Age (Recap Lesson 03)

### The Logic of Numbers

Forget the complicated math of our neighbors. Here, we keep it simple:

*   60 = Soixante
*   70 = **Septante** (Sept + ante. Logical!)
*   80 = Quatre-vingts
*   90 = **Nonante**

> **Rule:** We strictly use **SEPTANTE** and **NONANTE**. "Soixante-dix" and "Quatre-vingt-dix" are not used here.

### Challenge 3: The Right Price ğŸ’¶ ğŸ¯

<details>

## 3. My Family & Relatives (Recap Lesson 04)

### The Trap of "Mine, Yours, His/Hers"

Do not translate "His" or "Her" literally. In French, the word agrees with **the person/object being possessed** (grammatically speaking!), not with the owner.

*   C'est le pÃ¨re de Sophie. -> C'est **son** pÃ¨re.

Imagine you are a spy or a superhero. Create your new identity card in French!

*Example:*

## 4. Final Grand Challenge: "The Expat in Brussels"

Here is a full text. It contains **5 horrible mistakes** that hurt a Belgian's eyes (and ears). Find them and correct them!

> "Bonjour ! Je suis Mark. Je suis 32 ans. J'habite Bruxelles. Mon femme s'appelle Anna. Elle est amÃ©ricaine. Nous avons deux enfants. Notre fils a trois ans et notre fille est soixante-dix jours."

**ğŸ•µï¸â€â™‚ï¸ Find the 5 mistakes:**

<summary>ğŸ‘€ See full correction</summary>

**The correct text:**

## ğŸ§ Let's Start! What do you do?

### Listen to this dialogue

**Tom meets Marie at a networking event in Brussels:**

> **Marie :** Bonjour ! Je m'appelle Marie. Et vous ?
> 
> **Tom :** Bonjour ! Je suis Tom. EnchantÃ© !
> 
> **Marie :** **Vous faites quoi** dans la vie ?

> **Tom :** Ah, c'est intÃ©ressant ! **Votre** Ã©cole est oÃ¹ ?
>

### ğŸ” Comprehension

**Answer the questions:**

1. What is Tom's job?

## ğŸ” Observation 1: Saying your job

**Look at the dialogue:**

> **Tom :** Je suis **ingÃ©nieur**.  
> **Marie :** Je suis **professeure**.

**What did you notice?**

### Vocabulary: Common professions

|:---------|:--------|:--------|
| professeur | professeure | teacher |
| ingÃ©nieur | ingÃ©nieure | engineer |

| infirmier | infirmiÃ¨re | nurse |

| informaticien | informaticienne | IT specialist |
| Ã©tudiant | Ã©tudiante | student |

**ğŸ’¡ Note:** Some professions don't change (mÃ©decin, comptable).

## âœï¸ Practice 1: What's your job?

**Say your profession:**

"Je suis [profession]."

## ğŸ” Observation 2: Asking about someone's job

### Other ways to ask:

|:---------|:--------|:----------|

## ğŸ§  Grammar Focus: Asking Questions (Part 2) - The 3 Registers

In French, there are **3 ways** to ask the same question, depending on who you are talking to.

### 1. The 3 Ways to Ask ğŸ—£ï¸

| Register | Structure | Tone | Example |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Familier** | Statement + **?** (Intonation) | Friends / Oral | *Tu habites oÃ¹ ?* |
| **Standard** | **Est-ce que**... ? | Generic / Polite | *OÃ¹ **est-ce que** tu habites ?* |

> **ğŸ’¡ The Magic Phrase:** "**Est-ce que**" (pronounced "Ess-kuh") literally means "Is it that...". It allows you to transform any sentence into a clear question without changing the word order!

### 2. The 5 "Ws" (Question Words) ğŸ”‘

| **OÃ¹** | Where | *Tu travailles **oÃ¹** ?* |

| **Comment** | How | ***Comment** Ã§a va ?* |

### ğŸ¯ Activity 2: The Curious Colleague (Question Words)
Complete the questions with the correct word: **OÃ¹**, **Quand**, **Comment**, **Pourquoi**, **Qui**.

1.  Tu travailles __________ ? -> Ã€ Bruxelles.

---

## ğŸ” Observation 3: The verb "travailler" (to work)

> **Tom :** Je **travaille** dans une entreprise informatique.

### Conjugation: Travailler (to work)

| FranÃ§ais | English |
|:---------|:--------|

## âœï¸ Practice 2: Where do you work?

<details>
<summary>ğŸ“ Answers</summary>

1. Je **travaille** dans un bureau.
2. Tu **travailles** oÃ¹ ?

</details>

---

## ğŸ” Observation 4: Where you work

**The pattern:** Je travaille **dans** + un/une + [place]

### Common workplaces

| FranÃ§ais | English |
|:---------|:--------|
| dans un bureau | in an office |
| dans une entreprise | in a company |

| dans un hÃ´pital | in a hospital |

## ğŸ” Observation 5: Notre, Votre, Leur (Plural Owners)

**Look at these sentences from the dialogue:**

**ğŸ’¡ Easy:** Unlike *mon/ma/mes*, there is no gender change!
- **Notre** pÃ¨re / **Notre** mÃ¨re (Same word!)
- **Votre** frÃ¨re / **Votre** sÅ“ur

---

## âœï¸ Practice 3: Notre, Votre, Leur

# LeÃ§on 01 : Commander au restaurant

**Niveau** : A1.2  
**DurÃ©e estimÃ©e** : 2-3 heures  
**Objectifs** : Order food in a restaurant, understand a menu, use polite expressions

---

## Let's Start! At the restaurant

### Listen to this dialogue

**Tom and Sophie have dinner at a restaurant in Brussels:**

> **Serveur :** Bonsoir ! Vous avez rÃ©servÃ© ?
> 
> **Sophie :** Oui, une table pour deux au nom de Sophie.
> 
> **Serveur :** TrÃ¨s bien. Suivez-moi. Voici le menu.
> 
> *(quelques minutes plus tard)*
> 
> **Serveur :** Vous avez choisi ?
> 
> **Sophie :** Oui. **Je voudrais** la soupe Ã  l'oignon en entrÃ©e.
> 
> **Tom :** Et moi, **je prends** la salade CÃ©sar.
> 
> **Serveur :** Et comme plat principal ?
> 
> **Sophie :** **Pour moi**, le steak-frites, **saignant** s'il vous plaÃ®t.
> 
> **Tom :** Et **pour moi**, les moules-frites.
> 
> **Serveur :** Parfait. Et comme boisson ?
> 
> **Tom :** Une carafe d'eau et deux biÃ¨res, s'il vous plaÃ®t.
> 
> **Serveur :** TrÃ¨s bien. Je vous apporte Ã§a tout de suite.

---

### Comprehension

**Answer the questions:**

1. Did Sophie make a reservation?
2. What does Sophie order as a starter?
3. How does Sophie like her steak cooked?
4. What does Tom order as a main course?
5. What do they order to drink?

<summary>Answers</summary>

1. Yes, a table for two

---

## Observation 1: Ordering expressions

**Look at how they order:**

> **Je voudrais** la soupe Ã  l'oignon.  
> **Je prends** la salade CÃ©sar.  
> **Pour moi**, le steak-frites.

### Ways to order

| French | English | Politeness |
|:-------|:--------|:-----------|
| Je voudrais... | I would like... | Very polite |
| J'aimerais... | I would like... | Very polite |

## Practice 1: Order your meal

## Observation 2: Restaurant vocabulary

| l'entrÃ©e | starter/appetizer |

| le poulet | chicken |

## Observation 3: How do you like your steak?

### Steak cooking levels

| French | English | Description |

## Practice 2: Complete the order

**You :** Oui. Comme _____________ (starter), je voudrais la soupe.

**Serveur :** Et comme plat principal ?

**You :** Une _____________ (carafe) d'eau, s'il vous plaÃ®t.

<details>
<summary>Answers</summary>

2. Ã  point

</details>

---

## Observation 4: Asking for the bill

**At the end of the meal:**

> **Tom :** L'addition, s'il vous plaÃ®t.
> 
> **Serveur :** VoilÃ . Ã‡a fait 45 euros.
> 
> **Tom :** Je peux payer par carte ?
> 
> **Serveur :** Oui, bien sÃ»r.

### Useful expressions

| French | English |
|:-------|:--------|
| L'addition, s'il vous plaÃ®t. | The bill, please. |
| C'est combien ? | How much is it? |
| Je peux payer par carte ? | Can I pay by card? |
| Vous acceptez les espÃ¨ces ? | Do you accept cash? |
| Le service est compris ? | Is service included? |
| Gardez la monnaie. | Keep the change. |

---

## Culture: Dining in Belgium

### Read this testimony

**Marc, Belgian restaurant owner:**

> "In Belgium, we take our time at restaurants. A meal can last 2-3 hours â€“ it's a social experience! Tipping isn't obligatory because service is included in the price, but you can round up the bill or leave 5-10% for excellent service."

### Belgian restaurant customs

| Topic | Information |
|:------|:------------|
| Reservations | Recommended for dinner, especially weekends |
| Service charge | Included in prices |
| Tipping | Optional, 5-10% for great service |
| Meal times | Lunch 12-14h, Dinner 19-21h |
| Dress code | Smart casual for most restaurants |

### Belgian specialties

| Dish | Description |
|:-----|:------------|
| Moules-frites | Mussels with fries â€“ national dish! |
| Carbonnade flamande | Beef stewed in beer |
| Waterzooi | Creamy chicken or fish stew |
| Vol-au-vent | Chicken in creamy sauce |
| Stoemp | Mashed potatoes with vegetables |

---

### Exercise 1: Role-play at a restaurant

4. You order a starter and main course

## Grammar: The verb "prendre" (to take/have)

### Complete conjugation

| Subject | Conjugation |

| Je | prends |
| Tu | prends |
| Il/Elle/On | prend |
| Nous | prenons |
| Vous | prenez |
| Ils/Elles | prennent |

| French | English |
|:-------|:--------|
| Je prends le menu du jour. | I'll have the daily special. |
| Qu'est-ce que vous prenez ? | What will you have? |
| On prend l'addition. | We'll take the bill. |

---

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

### Mistake 1: "Je veux" instead of "Je voudrais"

| Too direct | Polite |
|:-----------|:-------|
| Je veux une pizza. | **Je voudrais** une pizza. |

**"Je veux" sounds demanding. Use "Je voudrais" in restaurants!**

### Mistake 2: Forgetting the article

| Incorrect | Correct |
|:----------|:--------|
| Je voudrais soupe | Je voudrais **la** soupe |

**Always use articles (le/la/les) when ordering!**

### Mistake 3: Wrong steak cooking term

| Incorrect | Correct |
|:----------|:--------|
| Medium | **Ã€ point** |
| Rare | **Saignant** |

**Use French terms for steak doneness!**

---

## Self-Evaluation

- [ ] I know menu vocabulary (entrÃ©e, plat, dessert)

- [ ] I can ask for the bill and pay
- [ ] I understand Belgian dining customs

### Additional activities

- **Restaurant visit:** Practice ordering in French at a real restaurant

- **Roleplay:** Practice with a friend or language partner

## Practice 1: Write the time

**Write these times in French:**

## Observation 4: Asking about time

## Practice 2: Complete the dialogue

**Fill in the blanks:**

**You :** Pardon, _____________ heure est-il ?

2. est
3. Ã

## Culture: Time in Belgium

### Read this testimony

**Marc, Belgian businessman:**

> "Belgians are quite punctual for professional meetings â€“ arrive on time or even 5 minutes early. For social events, it's acceptable to be 10-15 minutes late. Opening hours can vary: most shops close around 18h, but some small shops close for lunch between 12h and 14h. Sunday is generally a quiet day â€“ many shops are closed."

## Observation 1: Comparatives with "plus...que"

## Practice 1: Form comparatives

**Complete with plus, moins, or aussi:**

## Observation 5: Expressing preferences

**Look at these expressions:**

## Culture: Belgian preferences

### Read this testimony

**Marie, Belgian food critic:**

> "Belgians are quite particular about their food choices. We prefer quality over quantity. For example, we prefer artisanal chocolates to industrial ones, and craft beers to mass-produced ones. In restaurants, Belgians tend to prefer local, seasonal ingredients. We're also loyal to our favorite places â€“ we keep going back to the same bakery, the same butcher, the same cafÃ©."

## Practice 2: Express your preferences

### The three comparative forms

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

### Mistake 1: Using "plus bon"

| Incorrect | Correct |

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

| Incorrect | Correct |
|:----------|:--------|

### Mistake 2: Wrong pronoun

# LeÃ§on 01 : Souvenirs d'enfance

**Niveau** : A2.1  
**DurÃ©e estimÃ©e** : 2-3 heures  
**Objectifs** : Talk about childhood memories, discover the imparfait tense for habits

---

## Let's Start! Sophie's childhood memories

### Listen to Sophie

**Sophie, 35 years old, talks about her childhood in Namur:**

> "Quand j'**Ã©tais** petite, j'**habitais** Ã  Namur, dans le sud de la Belgique. Ma ville **Ã©tait** calme et jolie.
> 
> AprÃ¨s l'Ã©cole, je **jouais** avec mes amis dans le parc. On **regardait** la tÃ©lÃ© le soir, en famille. J'**adorais** les dessins animÃ©s !
> 
> Le week-end, nous **mangions** souvent des gaufres. Ma grand-mÃ¨re les **prÃ©parait** pour nous. C'**Ã©tait** dÃ©licieux !
> 
> Ã€ l'Ã©poque, il n'y **avait** pas d'internet. La vie **Ã©tait** diffÃ©rente..."

---

### Observation: What do you notice?

**Look at the bold verbs. Answer the questions:**

1. What period of her life is Sophie talking about?
   - [ ] Yesterday
   - [ ] Her childhood (distant past)
   - [ ] Tomorrow

2. Is she describing...
   - [ ] A single action that happened once
   - [ ] Habits and situations that repeated

3. Look at the verb endings: habit**ais**, jou**ais**, regard**ait**, mang**ions**...
   - What do they have in common?

### Answers

1. **Her childhood** - She says "quand j'Ã©tais petite"
2. **Habits** - "souvent", "le week-end", "le soir" = regular things
3. We see -ais, -ait, -ions... These are endings of a new tense!

---

## Discovery: A new past tense

### The tense Sophie uses is called the IMPARFAIT

**The imparfait is used to describe:**
- **Past habits:** "Je jouais dans le parc." (= I used to play regularly)
- **Descriptions:** "Ma ville Ã©tait calme." (The city was calm)
- **Ongoing situations:** "J'habitais Ã  Namur." (I was living/lived in Namur)

**In English:** "I used to..." or "I was ...ing"

---

### Return to Sophie's text

**Read again and identify:**

| What Sophie describes | Phrase from text |
|:---------------------|:----------------|
| Where she lived | "J'habitais Ã  Namur" |
| What she did after school | ? |
| What she watched in the evening | ? |
| What she ate on weekends | ? |
| Who prepared the waffles | ? |

### Answers

| What Sophie describes | Phrase from text |
|:---------------------|:----------------|
| Where she lived | J'habitais Ã  Namur |
| What she did after school | Je jouais avec mes amis |
| What she watched in the evening | On regardait la tÃ©lÃ© |
| What she ate on weekends | Nous mangions des gaufres |
| Who prepared the waffles | Ma grand-mÃ¨re les prÃ©parait |

---

## Observation 2: How to form the imparfait

**Look at the pattern:**

| Infinitive | Nous (present) | Stem | Imparfait |
|:-----------|:---------------|:-----|:----------|
| habiter | nous habit**ons** | habit- | j'habit**ais** |
| jouer | nous jou**ons** | jou- | je jou**ais** |
| manger | nous mang**eons** | mange- | je mange**ais** |
| regarder | nous regard**ons** | regard- | je regard**ais** |

### The rule

1. Take the **nous** form in present tense
2. Remove **-ons**
3. Add imparfait endings

### Imparfait endings

| Subject | Ending | Example |
|:--------|:-------|:--------|
| Je | -ais | je parlais |
| Tu | -ais | tu parlais |
| Il/Elle/On | -ait | il parlait |
| Nous | -ions | nous parlions |
| Vous | -iez | vous parliez |
| Ils/Elles | -aient | ils parlaient |

---

## Practice 1: Form the imparfait

**Transform to imparfait:**

1. Je (habiter) Ã  Paris â†’ _______________
2. Tu (jouer) au football â†’ _______________
3. Elle (regarder) la tÃ©lÃ© â†’ _______________
4. Nous (manger) ensemble â†’ _______________
5. Ils (travailler) beaucoup â†’ _______________

### Answers

1. J'**habitais** Ã  Paris
2. Tu **jouais** au football
3. Elle **regardait** la tÃ©lÃ©
4. Nous **mangions** ensemble
5. Ils **travaillaient** beaucoup

---

## Observation 3: ÃŠtre - the exception

**"ÃŠtre" is the only irregular verb in imparfait. The stem is "Ã©t-"**

| Subject | ÃŠtre (imparfait) |
|:--------|:-----------------|
| J' | Ã©tais |
| Tu | Ã©tais |
| Il/Elle/On | Ã©tait |
| Nous | Ã©tions |
| Vous | Ã©tiez |
| Ils/Elles | Ã©taient |

---

## Culture: Childhood in Belgium

### Read this testimony

**Marc, Belgian teacher:**

> "Belgian childhood has changed a lot! In the 1980s, children played outside until dark. There were no smartphones, no internet. Families watched TV together â€“ mostly French or Flemish shows. On Sundays, grandparents visited, and we ate together. Belgian children still have this tradition of Sunday family lunch, but much has changed with technology."

### Comparing past and present

| Before (Imparfait) | Now (Present) |
|:-------------------|:--------------|
| On jouait dehors | On joue aux jeux vidÃ©o |
| Il n'y avait pas d'internet | Tout le monde a internet |
| On regardait la tÃ©lÃ© en famille | Chacun a son Ã©cran |
| On mangeait ensemble | On mange parfois sÃ©parÃ©ment |

---

## Speaking Practice

### Exercise 1: Your childhood

**Talk about YOUR childhood using imparfait:**

1. OÃ¹ est-ce que tu habitais ?
2. Ã€ quelle Ã©cole tu allais ?
3. Qu'est-ce que tu faisais aprÃ¨s l'Ã©cole ?
4. Qu'est-ce que tu mangeais le week-end ?

### Exercise 2: Compare

**Compare your childhood to now:**

"Avant, je... Maintenant, je..."

---

## Writing Practice

**Write about your childhood (80-100 words):**

Include:
- Where you lived
- What you did regularly
- What you liked
- What was different from now

Use at least 6 verbs in imparfait!

---

## Grammar: Imparfait summary

### Formation

1. Take the NOUS form of present tense
2. Remove -ons
3. Add imparfait endings: -ais, -ais, -ait, -ions, -iez, -aient

### Uses

| Use | Example |
|:----|:--------|
| Past habits | Je jouais tous les jours |
| Descriptions | Ma ville Ã©tait petite |
| Ongoing states | J'habitais Ã  Bruxelles |
| Background information | Il faisait beau |

### Only exception: ÃŠTRE

| Subject | Conjugation |
|:--------|:------------|
| Je/Tu | Ã©tais |
| Il/Elle/On | Ã©tait |
| Nous | Ã©tions |
| Vous | Ã©tiez |
| Ils/Elles | Ã©taient |

---

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

### Mistake 1: Wrong stem for irregular verbs

| Incorrect | Correct |
|:----------|:--------|
| Je fais-ais | Je **faisais** (from "nous faisons" â†’ fais-) |
| Je peux-ais | Je **pouvais** (from "nous pouvons" â†’ pouv-) |

### Mistake 2: Confusing with passÃ© composÃ©

| PassÃ© composÃ© | Imparfait |
|:--------------|:----------|
| Single action | Habit/state |
| J'ai mangÃ© hier | Je mangeais souvent |

### Mistake 3: Wrong endings

| Incorrect | Correct |
|:----------|:--------|
| nous parlais | nous parl**ions** |
| vous parlait | vous parl**iez** |

---

## Self-Evaluation

**Check what you can do:**

- [ ] I understand when to use imparfait
- [ ] I can form imparfait for regular verbs
- [ ] I know the conjugation of "Ãªtre" in imparfait
- [ ] I can talk about my childhood
- [ ] I can describe past habits

---

## Extra Resources

### Additional activities

- **Interview:** Ask a French speaker about their childhood
- **Write:** A paragraph about life 20 years ago
- **Compare:** Belgian childhood vs childhood in your country

### Next lesson

> **LeÃ§on 02 : Description et contexte**  
> You'll learn to use imparfait for setting the scene!

---

*Bonne continuation !*

## Practice 2: Your life before

> "Avant de venir en Belgique, j'habitais Ã  Lyon. Je travaillais dans un hÃ´pital. La vie Ã©tait trÃ¨s diffÃ©rente : je commenÃ§ais Ã  6h du matin ! Le week-end, je faisais du ski dans les Alpes. Maintenant, je travaille moins et je profite de la vie bruxelloise. Mais les montagnes me manquent parfois."

# LeÃ§on 03 : Mon arrivÃ©e en Belgique

### Comprehension

**Answer the questions:**

## Observation 1: Two tenses in one story

**Look at the text again. Notice there are TWO past tenses:**

### PassÃ© composÃ© (actions)

> Il **est arrivÃ©** en Belgique.  
> Il **a pris** un taxi.  
> Il **s'est perdu**.

### Imparfait (background/conditions)

> Il **faisait** froid.

> Le chauffeur **Ã©tait** sympa.

## Observation 2: The key difference

### Think of it like a movie:

| Imparfait | PassÃ© composÃ© |
|:----------|:--------------|
| The scene | The action |
| Background music | Plot events |

| Ongoing state | Completed event |

## Practice 1: Identify the tense

|:-------|:--------|

| hier | yesterday |
| Ã  ce moment-lÃ  | at that moment |
| finalement | finally |

### Words that suggest IMPARFAIT (ongoing/background):

| French | English |
|:-------|:--------|
| pendant que | while |
| quand (ongoing) | when |
| il y avait | there was |
| il faisait | it was (weather) |
| tous les jours | every day |
| d'habitude | usually |

## Observation 4: The "QUAND" structure

### Pattern 2: Repeated action (both imparfait)

> (When I was a child, I used to play football.)

---

## Practice 2: Fill in the correct tense

# LeÃ§on 08 : Mes projets en Belgique

>

## Observation 1: The futur simple

**Look at the verbs in bold:**

### The pattern for -ER and -IR verbs:

**INFINITIVE + endings**

| Subject | Ending | PARLER (infinitive) | Futur |
|:--------|:-------|:--------------------|:------|

|:-----------|:-----|:-----------|

|:-------|:--------|

---

## Culture: Future plans in Belgium

### Read this testimony

**Marie, Belgian career counselor:**

> "When talking about future plans in Belgium, Belgians tend to be realistic and somewhat modest. They might say 'J'espÃ¨re que je trouverai un travail' rather than 'Je trouverai un travail.' Using 'peut-Ãªtre' (maybe) or 'j'espÃ¨re' (I hope) shows you're not being overconfident. It's part of the Belgian pragmatic approach to life!"

### Useful expressions for future plans

| French | English |
|:-------|:--------|

| J'espÃ¨re que je... | I hope I'll... |

1. L'annÃ©e prochaine, je...
2. Dans 5 ans, je...
3. Un jour, je...

### Exercise 2: Interview a partner

**Ask about their future:**

- Qu'est-ce que tu feras l'Ã©tÃ© prochain ?

- Quel est ton plus grand projet ?

Include:
- Short-term plans (next weeks/months)
- Medium-term plans (next year)
- Long-term dreams (in the future)

Use at least 8 verbs in futur simple!

## Grammar: Regular futur simple

### Formation summary

| Verb type | Rule | Example |
|:----------|:-----|:--------|
| -ER verbs | infinitive + endings | parler â†’ parlerai |
| -IR verbs | infinitive + endings | finir â†’ finirai |

| Je prendreai | Je **prendrai** |
| Je attendreai | J'**attendrai** |

**Listen for the difference in pronunciation!**

### Mistake 3: Accent changes with -ER verbs

Some verbs change accents:
| Present | Futur |
|:--------|:------|
| j'achÃ¨te | j'achÃ¨t**e**rai |
| je prÃ©fÃ¨re | je prÃ©fÃ©r**e**rai |

# LeÃ§on 10 : Les temps du futur (Consolidation)

**Niveau** : A2.1  
**Type** : Consolidation  
**DurÃ©e estimÃ©e** : 2-3 heures  
**Objectifs** : Master futur simple and futur proche, compare both future tenses

---

## Review: Two ways to express future

### Futur proche (near future)

**ALLER (present) + INFINITIVE**

| Subject | Aller | Infinitive |
|:--------|:------|:-----------|
| Je | vais | manger |
| Tu | vas | partir |
| Il/Elle | va | travailler |

**Use:** Immediate plans, intentions, near future

### Futur simple (simple future)

**STEM + ENDINGS (-ai, -as, -a, -ons, -ez, -ont)**

| Regular | Irregular |
|:--------|:----------|
| je parlerai | je serai (Ãªtre) |
| tu finiras | tu auras (avoir) |
| il prendra | il ira (aller) |

**Use:** Predictions, formal contexts, more distant future

---

## Practice 1: Choose the best future

**Select futur proche (FP) or futur simple (FS) for each situation:**

1. Tomorrow's weather forecast â†’ _____
2. You're about to open a door for someone â†’ _____

6. An official announcement â†’ _____

### Answers

1. **FS** (Demain, il fera beau) - prediction
2. **FP** (Je vais ouvrir la porte) - immediate
3. **FS** (Dans 10 ans, je serai...) - distant future
4. **FP** (Ce soir, je vais dÃ®ner...) - near future
5. **Either** (Je vais t'aider / Je t'aiderai) - both work

---

## Practice 2: Transform between futures

**Rewrite using the other future tense:**

1. Je vais partir demain. â†’ (futur simple) _______________
2. Nous ferons une fÃªte. â†’ (futur proche) _______________

### Answers

2. Nous **allons faire** une fÃªte.
3. Tu **verras** le mÃ©decin ?

5. Ils **achÃ¨teront** une maison.

---

## Practice 3: Complete the dialogue

2. vais rester (near future, this weekend)

## Practice 5: Correct the errors

**Find and fix the mistakes:**

### Key irregular stems reminder

| Verb | Stem | Example |

### Belgian approach to the future

Belgians tend to be:

# LeÃ§on 11 : Ma routine quotidienne

**Niveau** : A2.1  
**DurÃ©e estimÃ©e** : 2-3 heures  
**Objectifs** : Learn direct object pronouns (COD), avoid repetition in speech

---

## Let's Start! Daily routine

### Listen to this dialogue

**Sophie asks about Tom's routine:**

> **Sophie :** Tu prends le petit-dÃ©jeuner le matin ?
> 
> **Tom :** Oui, je **le** prends vers 8h. Je mange des cÃ©rÃ©ales avec du lait.
> 
> **Sophie :** Tu lis le journal ?
> 
> **Tom :** Non, je ne **le** lis pas. Je prÃ©fÃ¨re Ã©couter la radio. Je **l'**Ã©coute pendant que je prÃ©pare le cafÃ©.
> 
> **Sophie :** Et tes emails, tu **les** vÃ©rifies le matin ?
> 
> **Tom :** Oui, je **les** vÃ©rifie tout de suite. Et je rÃ©ponds aux messages urgents, je **les** traite en premier.
> 
> **Sophie :** Tu fais du sport ?
> 
> **Tom :** Oui, je **le** fais le soir. Je vais Ã  la salle de sport. Je **la** trouve trÃ¨s bien Ã©quipÃ©e.
> 
> **Sophie :** Et moi, tu **me** vois parfois ? (rires)
> 
> **Tom :** Bien sÃ»r ! Je **te** vois tous les jours au bureau !

### Comprehension

1. When does Tom have breakfast?
2. Does he read the newspaper?

## Observation 1: Direct object pronouns

**Look at these sentences:**

> Tu prends **le petit-dÃ©jeuner** ? â†’ Oui, je **le** prends.  
> Tu lis **le journal** ? â†’ Non, je ne **le** lis pas.  
> Tu vÃ©rifies **tes emails** ? â†’ Oui, je **les** vÃ©rifie.

### What happened?

The noun (le petit-dÃ©jeuner, le journal, les emails) was replaced by a short word to avoid repetition.

### The direct object pronouns (COD)

| Pronoun | Replaces | Example |
|:--------|:---------|:--------|
| me (m') | me | Tu me vois ? |
| te (t') | you (informal) | Je te comprends. |
| le (l') | him / it (masc.) | Je le connais. |
| la (l') | her / it (fem.) | Je la regarde. |
| nous | us | Il nous appelle. |

---

## Observation 2: Position of pronouns

**Look at where the pronoun goes:**

> Je **le** prends.  
> Je ne **le** lis **pas**.  
> Je **l'**Ã©coute.

### Rule: Pronoun goes BEFORE the verb

| Affirmative | Negative |
|:------------|:---------|
| Je **le** mange. | Je ne **le** mange pas. |
| Je **les** vois. | Je ne **les** vois pas. |

> Je vais **le** faire. (pronoun before infinitive)

## Practice 1: Replace with pronouns

**Replace the underlined words with le, la, l', or les:**

1. Je prends **le bus** tous les jours. â†’ _______________
2. Elle regarde **la tÃ©lÃ©** le soir. â†’ _______________
3. Nous aimons **les films franÃ§ais**. â†’ _______________
4. Tu Ã©coutes **la radio** ? â†’ _______________

6. Il adore **son travail**. â†’ _______________

### Answers

1. Je **le** prends tous les jours.
2. Elle **la** regarde le soir.
3. Nous **les** aimons.
4. Tu **l'**Ã©coutes ?

---

## Observation 3: Elision (l' before vowels)

**Look at these examples:**

> J'**Ã©coute** la radio. â†’ Je **l'**Ã©coute.  
> J'**aime** ce film. â†’ Je **l'**aime.  
> J'**appelle** Marie. â†’ Je **l'**appelle.

### Rule: le/la â†’ l' before vowel or silent h

| Full form | Elided form |
|:----------|:------------|
| Je le aime | Je **l'**aime |
| Je la appelle | Je **l'**appelle |
| Je le Ã©coute | Je **l'**Ã©coute |

---

## Practice 2: Answer with pronouns

**Answer affirmatively using a pronoun:**

1. Tu connais mon frÃ¨re ? â†’ _______________
2. Elle prend le mÃ©tro ? â†’ _______________
3. Vous aimez les chocolats belges ? â†’ _______________
4. Tu regardes ce film ? â†’ _______________
5. Il finit le rapport ? â†’ _______________

### Answers

1. Oui, je **le** connais.
2. Oui, elle **le** prend.
3. Oui, nous **les** aimons.
4. Oui, je **le** regarde.
5. Oui, il **le** finit.

---

## Observation 4: With compound tenses

**Look at passÃ© composÃ©:**

> J'ai vu **le film**. â†’ Je **l'**ai vu.  
> Elle a lu **les emails**. â†’ Elle **les** a lus.

### Rule: Pronoun before the auxiliary (avoir/Ãªtre)

| Without pronoun | With pronoun |
|:----------------|:-------------|
| J'ai pris le bus | Je **l'**ai pris |
| Elle a vu les photos | Elle **les** a vues |

**Note:** Past participle agrees with preceding direct object!
- Je l'ai vu**e** (la = feminine)
- Je les ai vu**s** (les = masculine plural)
- Je les ai vu**es** (les = feminine plural)

---

## Practice 3: Transform to passÃ© composÃ©

**Rewrite with pronoun in passÃ© composÃ©:**

1. Je regarde le film. â†’ (passÃ© composÃ©) _______________
2. Elle lit les articles. â†’ (passÃ© composÃ©) _______________
3. Nous achetons la voiture. â†’ (passÃ© composÃ©) _______________
4. Tu finis le travail. â†’ (passÃ© composÃ©) _______________

### Answers

1. Je **l'**ai regardÃ©.
2. Elle **les** a lus.
3. Nous **l'**avons achetÃ©e. (la voiture = fem.)
4. Tu **l'**as fini.

---

## Culture: Avoiding repetition in French

### Read this

**French speakers strongly dislike repetition. Consider:**

| Repetitive (awkward) | Natural (with pronoun) |
|:--------------------|:-----------------------|
| Je prends le cafÃ©. Le cafÃ© est bon. | Je le prends. Il est bon. |
| Tu aimes les gaufres ? Je fais des gaufres. | Tu les aimes ? Je les fais. |

### Cultural note

> "In French, using pronouns isn't just grammatically correct â€“ it sounds more natural and elegant. Repeating nouns can sound childish or robotic to French speakers. Mastering pronouns will make your French flow much better!"

---

## Speaking Practice

### Exercise 1: Daily routine with pronouns

**Describe your routine, replacing nouns with pronouns after first mention:**

Example: "Le matin, je prends mon cafÃ©. Je le prends avec du lait..."

### Exercise 2: Q&A Practice

**Answer these questions using pronouns:**

1. Tu regardes les infos le matin ?
2. Tu prends le petit-dÃ©jeuner chez toi ?
3. Tu Ã©coutes de la musique au travail ?
4. Tu finis ton travail Ã  quelle heure ?

---

## Writing Practice

**Write about your daily routine (100 words):**

Use at least 8 direct object pronouns to avoid repetition.

Example:
"Je me rÃ©veille Ã  7h. Je prends mon tÃ©lÃ©phone et je le vÃ©rifie. J'ai beaucoup de messages, je les lis rapidement. Ensuite, je prends ma douche. AprÃ¨s, je prÃ©pare le petit-dÃ©jeuner. Je le prends en regardant les informations. Je les regarde sur mon tÃ©lÃ©phone..."

---

## Grammar: Complete COD reference

### Direct object pronouns

| Person | Pronoun | Example |
|:-------|:--------|:--------|
| 1st sing. | me (m') | Il me voit |
| 2nd sing. | te (t') | Je te comprends |

| Negative | ne + pronoun + verb + pas | Je ne le vois pas |
| PassÃ© composÃ© | before auxiliary | Je l'ai vu |
| With infinitive | before infinitive | Je vais le voir |
| Imperative affirm. | after verb with hyphen | Regarde-le ! |
| Imperative neg. | before verb | Ne le regarde pas ! |

---

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

### Mistake 1: Wrong position

| Incorrect | Correct |
|:----------|:--------|
| Je vois le | Je **le** vois |
| Je ai le vu | Je **l'**ai vu |

### Mistake 2: Forgetting elision

| Incorrect | Correct |
|:----------|:--------|
| Je le aime | Je **l'**aime |

### Mistake 3: No agreement in passÃ© composÃ©

| Incorrect | Correct |
|:----------|:--------|
| La lettre ? Je l'ai reÃ§u | Je l'ai reÃ§u**e** |

---

## Self-Evaluation

**Check what you can do:**

- [ ] I know all direct object pronouns

## Practice 1: Replace with COI pronouns

| Mot | DÃ©finition |

## 7. Mise en Pratique ComplÃ¨te

**Comparez l'Appartement A et l'Appartement B :**

| | Appartement A | Appartement B |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |

---

## 8. RÃ©capitulatif et Erreurs Ã  Ã©viter

### Ce qu'il faut retenir

2. **Comparatifs** :
   - QualitÃ© : *Plus/Moins/Aussi* + Adjectif + *que*

# LeÃ§on 17 : Les meilleures adresses

**DurÃ©e estimÃ©e** : 2-3 heures  
**Objectifs** : Use superlatives, give recommendations, describe extremes

---

## Let's Start! Best of Brussels

### Listen to this text

**Sophie gives Tom recommendations:**

> "Tu veux dÃ©couvrir Bruxelles ? Je vais te donner **les meilleures adresses** !
>
> Pour le chocolat, Neuhaus est **le plus cÃ©lÃ¨bre**, mais Pierre Marcolini est **le meilleur** selon moi. C'est aussi **le plus cher** !
>
> Pour les frites, Maison Antoine fait **les meilleures frites** de Bruxelles. C'est toujours **la plus longue** queue, mais Ã§a vaut la peine.

> **Le musÃ©e le plus intÃ©ressant** ? Le MusÃ©e Magritte. Pour l'art contemporain, le Wiels est **le plus moderne**.

---

## Observation 1: Forming superlatives

**Look at these structures:**

> **Le plus** cÃ©lÃ¨bre  
> **La plus** longue

### The pattern

| Gender | Superlative | Example |

## Observation 2: Superlative with "de"

|:-------|:--------|
| de Bruxelles | in Brussels |

| Adjective | Comparative | Superlative |

### Examples

## Culture: Best of Belgium

### Answers

2. **le plus intÃ©ressant** musÃ©e OR le musÃ©e **le plus intÃ©ressant**
3. **le meilleur** restaurant

---

## Speaking Practice

### Exercise 1: Give your recommendations

**Use superlatives to recommend:**

1. Le meilleur restaurant que tu connais
2. Le plus beau endroit Ã  visiter
3. La meilleure biÃ¨re que tu as goÃ»tÃ©e

## Writing Practice

**Write a "Best of Brussels" guide (120 words):**

Include:

Example:
"**Le meilleur chocolat** : Pierre Marcolini. C'est le plus raffinÃ© de Bruxelles..."

## Grammar: Superlatives summary

### Formation

| Type | Structure | Example |

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

### Mistake 1: "le plus bon"

## Observation 1: Demonstrative pronouns

> **Ceux-ci** sont franÃ§ais.

### What are these words replacing?

They replace a noun to avoid repetition:

## Observation 2: The four forms

**Demonstrative pronouns match the noun they replace:**

| Gender/Number | Pronoun |

| Feminine singular | celle |

## Observation 3: Three ways to use them

## 2. Grammaire 1 : Faire un choix avec LEQUEL

Pour demander *"Quel objet ?"* sans rÃ©pÃ©ter le nom, on utilise le pronom interrogatif **Lequel**.

## 4. Grammaire 2 : La Possession (Le mien, le tien...)

| **Vous** (Votre/Vos) | C'est **le vÃ´tre** | C'est **la vÃ´tre** | Ce sont **les vÃ´tres** |

> **Attention Ã  l'accent !**

## 6. Mise en Pratique : Lequel est le tien ?

### Erreurs FrÃ©quentes

| :--- | :--- | :--- |

| C'est Ã  moi. (Correct mais basique) | C'est **le mien**. | Plus Ã©lÃ©gant et Ã©vite la rÃ©pÃ©tition. |
| Tu veux quel ? | Tu veux **lequel** ? | "Quel" est toujours suivi d'un nom. |

# LeÃ§on 08 : Je ne fume plus (Les OpposÃ©s)

**Niveau** : A2.2

## 2. La Logique : Les Couples OpposÃ©s (POSTIF vs NÃ‰GATIF)

Si la question utilise le mot Ã  gauche, la rÃ©ponse utilise le mot Ã  droite.

| **Tout le monde** (Everybody) | **Personne** (No one) | **Tout le monde** est lÃ  ? â†’ **Personne** n'est lÃ . |
| **Quelque chose** (Something) | **Rien** (Nothing) | Tu manges **quelque chose** ? â†’ Je ne mange **rien**. |

| **Quelque part** (Somewhere) | **Nulle part** (Nowhere) | Tu vas **quelque part** ? â†’ Je ne vais **nulle part**. |
| **Souvent / Toujours** (Always) | **Jamais** (Never) | Tu viens **souvent** ? â†’ Je ne viens **jamais**. |

> **RÃ¨gle d'or :**

---

## 3. Pratique 1 : Trouvez l'opposÃ©

**RÃ©pondez Ã  la question par la nÃ©gative (utilisez l'opposÃ© logique) :**

## 4. Zoom sur : "Ne ... Plus" (ArrÃªt d'une habitude)

On utilise **ne ... plus** pour dire qu'une action a stoppÃ©. C'est la fin d'une situation passÃ©e.

- *Avant :* Je fumais. (Positif)

## 6. Pratique 2 : Au PassÃ© ComposÃ©

**Mettez les phrases au PassÃ© ComposÃ© :**

### RÃ©ponses

---

## 7. Mise en Situation : L'Interrogatoire

**Vous Ãªtes la police. Posez des questions avec les mots positifs. Le suspect rÃ©pond non.**

**Police :** Vous avez vu **quelqu'un** Ã  20h ?
**Suspect :** Non, je ___________________________________.

---

---

## 8. RÃ©capitulatif et Erreurs Ã  Ã©viter

### Ce qu'il faut retenir
- **Logique** : Ã€ chaque mot positif correspond un nÃ©gatif (*Quelqu'un* $\neq$ *Personne*).

## Auto-Ã‰valuation

- [ ] Je sais que "Personne" et "Nulle part" se placent APRES le participe passÃ©.

## Observation 1: The conditional for politeness

## Practice 1: Form the conditional

## Observation 4: Irregular stems (same as futur simple!)

## Practice 2: Transform to polite requests

## Observation 5: Polite expressions for different situations

## Speaking Practice

## 9. RÃ©capitulatif et Erreurs Ã  Ã©viter

### Ce qu'il faut retenir

- **Les 5 verbes clÃ©s** : Fasse, Sois, Aie, Aille, Puisse.

# LeÃ§on 16 : Il faut que tu viennes

**Niveau** : B1.1  
**DurÃ©e estimÃ©e** : 2-3 heures  
**Objectifs** : Discover the subjunctive mood and its formation

---

## Let's Start! A new mood

### Listen to this dialogue

**Sophie organizes a surprise party:**

> **Sophie :** Tom, j'organise une fÃªte surprise pour Marie. Il faut que tu **viennes** !
> 
> **Tom :** Bien sÃ»r ! Qu'est-ce qu'il faut que je **fasse** ?

> **Tom :** D'accord. Tu veux que j'**apporte** quelque chose d'autre ?
> 
> **Sophie :** Oui, il faut que tu **prennes** aussi des boissons. Et je voudrais que tu **sois** lÃ  Ã  18h.

1. What is Sophie organizing?

---

## Observation 1: What is the subjunctive?

**Look at these sentences:**

> Il faut que tu **viennes**.  
> Je veux que tu **fasses** Ã§a.  
> Il est important que tu **arrives** tÃ´t.

### The subjunctive is a MOOD, not a tense

It expresses:
- Necessity (il faut que...)
- Desire/will (je veux que...)
- Importance (il est important que...)
- Subjectivity, emotion, doubt

**Compare:**

| Indicative (facts) | Subjunctive (necessity/will) |
|:-------------------|:-----------------------------|
| Tu viens. (You're coming) | Il faut que tu viennes. (You must come) |
| Tu fais Ã§a. (You do that) | Je veux que tu fasses Ã§a. (I want you to do that) |

---

## Observation 2: Formation of the subjunctive

### For most verbs: Take ILS form of present, remove -ent, add subjunctive endings

| Step | Example (parler) |
|:-----|:-----------------|
| 1. ils parlent | (ils form) |
| 2. parl- | (remove -ent) |
| 3. que je parle, tu parles... | (add endings) |

### Subjunctive endings

| Subject | Ending |
|:--------|:-------|
| que je | -e |
| que tu | -es |
| qu'il/elle | -e |
| que nous | -ions |
| que vous | -iez |
| qu'ils/elles | -ent |

---

## Observation 3: Regular verb conjugations

| que vous | parliez |
| qu'ils/elles | parlent |

### Verbs ending in -IR (finir)

| que je | sois |

| savoir | que je sache |
| vouloir | que je veuille |

---

## Practice 1: Conjugate in subjunctive

**Complete with the subjunctive:**

1. Il faut que je _____________ (parler) franÃ§ais.
2. Il faut que tu _____________ (finir) ton travail.
3. Il faut qu'elle _____________ (Ãªtre) Ã  l'heure.

## Culture: The subjunctive in everyday French

### Read this

**Le subjonctif au quotidien:**

> "Le subjonctif est trÃ¨s courant en franÃ§ais. Contrairement Ã  l'anglais oÃ¹ il a presque disparu, le subjonctif franÃ§ais est utilisÃ© tous les jours. Les expressions comme 'il faut que' et 'je veux que' sont essentielles. Les francophones natifs l'utilisent automatiquement, mÃªme si les rÃ¨gles peuvent sembler complexes. Les Belges utilisent souvent 'il faut bien que' pour adoucir une demande."

## Speaking Practice
